segments.key_quote: So the reaction of the son of Shamika Rishi Shringi was to become very angry against the king and curse the king to die within seven days.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 46th verse of the 18th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining the context of Shamika Rishi's reaction to his son cursing King Pariksit.
segments.transcript: Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet. In this session we will be discussing from the 46th verse of the 18th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. The verse: Dharmapalo Narapati Hi Satu Samrat Brihat Shavaha Sakshat Mahabhagavato Rajarshir Hayamedhayat Rajarshir Hayamedhayat Kshutrut Shrama Uthodino Naivasmat Sapa Arhati. The meaning of this verse is: The emperor Pariksit is a pious king. He is highly celebrated and is the first-class devotee of the personality of Godhead, equal capacity to all stations. He is a saint amongst royalty and he has performed many hard sacrifices. When such a king is tired and fatigued, being stricken with hunger and thirst, he does not at all deserve to be cursed. These are words spoken by Shamika Rishi on learning from his son that his son had cursed King Emperor Pariksit just because Emperor Pariksit, when he was thirsty and hungry, he came looking for water in Shamika Rishi's ashram. Not finding water, he became upset and he took a dead snake and put it round the shoulder of the Rishi who was sitting in meditation in trance
